We're learning more about why there were massive explosions at a warehouse in China last week that killed more than a hundred people.

For more on this, we turn to NPR's Frank Langfitt in Shanghai.
Frank, good morning.
And good morning, David.
So there seems to be a really important development here.
Tell me about this co-owner of the warehouse.
What's his story, and what's he saying?
Well, David, the guy's name is Dong Shexuan.
He was a major shareholder in Rui Hai International Logistics.
That's the company that owned the warehouse.
More importantly, he's the son of the former police chief for the Tianjin Port, which is where this happened.
And right now, Dong is in police custody, and he had gave this kind of confession interview to the government's new China News Service.
And what he said is he used his dad's connections to get the warehouse approved.
Now, legally, the warehouse with these kinds of dangerous chemicals, it's got to be a thousand meters from residential neighborhoods for safety reasons.
